title: drive-give-open-golf-legends-the-recognition-deserve
story: Stevie Hill, captain of Musselburgh Old Course Golf Club, wants to see game legends David lsquoDeaconrsquo Brown, Bob Ferguson and Jack White remembered in the townrsquos graveyard at Inveresk.While out for his daily exercise during the Covid- lockdown, he noticed there were grave markers for Mr Ferguson, a three-time Open champion, and Mr White, but no headstones.He also wants to properly recognise Mr Brown, who is buried there too.He said he was keen that headstones with details of their victories be installed, as a reminder of their sporting prowess on the links and their connections with Musselburgh, which is known as lsquothe cradle of golf rsquo.A social media plea put him in touch with relatives of Mr Brown and Mr Ferguson but, so far, hehas been unable to locate the family of Mr White, who was born at Pefferside, near Whitekirk, in  and died in Musselburgh in , aged .He is best remembered as the winner of the  Open Championship at Royal St Georgersquos.Mr Hill, a member of the Society of Hickory Golfers, said he was anxious to get their permission before launching a GoFundMe online page in a bid to raise funds to purchase and install the headstones.Mr Ferguson, who was born in Musselburgh in  and died in the town in , won a hat-trick of consecutive titles at the Open Championship in  ,  and .In addition to the three Open wins, he posted top- finishes seven times.He became Custodian of the Links at Musselburgh and taught the boys of Loretto School how to play golf.Mr Brown, who born in Musselburgh in  and died, aged , at Inveresk in , won the  Open Championship and finished second in the  US Open.In total, he had  top- finishes in major championship tournaments.Mr Hill explained that it would cost around pound for each of the three headstones, with additional costs for their installation in the cemetery.He said: ldquoMany youngsters learned to play golf at the Old Course, which attracts visitors from all over the world. I want to give these three golfers the recognition they deserve.The cemetery is also the last resting place of famous Open Champions Willie Park Snr, the first to lt the coveted title in  at Prestwick, going on to become a four-time Open champion, and his son Willie Park Jnr, both from Wallyford.In , Musselburgh Town Council, with the Royal Musselburgh Golf Club, erected a stone to mark Willie Park Snrrsquos grave.This, and Willie Jnrrsquos wall-mounted stone, were cleaned and re-lettered with help from the Old Musselburgh Club in .The only Open champion whose grave is as yet undiscovered is that of their relative Mungo Park, who won in , coming from a career as a seaman to have his name inscribed on the Claret Jug.No burial marker has yet been found for him.He and Mr Brown were residents at the Inveresk Combination Poorhouse in the last years of their lives, although when Mr Brown lived there it would have been known as Wedderburn House.Willie Park Snrrsquos great grandson, Mungo Park, praised Mr Hillrsquos efforts, saying: ldquoI am glad to hear that Musselburghrsquos golfers continue to take pride in their history.ldquoThe town deserves recognition for the huge contribution that it made to the history of the game in the th century, when it was both the lsquocradle of golf rsquo and its driving force.He added: ldquoMusselburgh professionals were among the first to take the game to the rest of the world.ldquoIt is fitting that all of the six Open Champions who lived in the town should be properly recognised. ldquoThese six exceptional golfers won  Open Championships between them but there were many others from the town who contributed much to the game and won signicant competitions throughout the world.ldquoMusselburghrsquos golf had strength and depth.ldquoI hope that this renewed interest in Musselburghrsquos Open champions and its history will continue to grow, so that the town can make the most of its reputation, and benefit from its unique place in golf history.

title: bid-turn-former-haddington-church-flats-hold
story: Haddington School of Dance and Music has withdrawn plans to turn Newton Port Church into new homes.The dance and music school is on the lookout for new premises, as the upkeep costs of the building are problematic.However, the proposals, which were submitted to East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department in January, have since been withdrawn.A spokeswoman for the local authority expected new proposals to be submitted in the future.Issues with the original application had been identied as the building is listed and also sits within the townrsquos conservation area.Documents included in the withdrawn planning application highlight the dficulties facing the dance school business, including the maintenance of the building, which is more than  years old.It reads: ldquoThe necessary modernisation of heating, electrics and plumbing, together with roofing, prevention of water ingress and ensuring safety from falling masonry, has been a recurrent expense.ldquoThe owners are proud to have restored the building to the current level.ldquoWhat were thought to be initial major renovation expenses have, however, continued year on year. The building is due for further major works of damp proofing and roof repairs to the extension.ldquoThere are several areas where water ingress has never been fully stopped.Originally, the building opened its doors as St Johnrsquos Church of Scotland, in . More recently, it was used by the congregation of St Maryrsquos as their church hall.However, the building, at the junction of Newton Port and Fortune Avenue, has been vandalised, with lead stolen from the roof and sky lights damaged.The document adds: ldquoIt has become clear that the ongoing costs of keeping the building wind and water tight, safe and up to modern standards for the current purpose are not a viable prospect for the future for the school.ldquoThe winter heating costs are prohibitive and the current school director cannot continue to run the school with accumulated losses.ldquoThe current owner of the school is now considering how best to continue to provide the community amenity into the future.ldquoShe considers that this specialised service will be best provided in a modern, easily maintained studio space. That could take the form of an industrial unit large enough to house the theatre rigging and studio equipment.

title: diamond-couple-toast-special-anniversary-garden-party
story: Pat and Ian Anderson have lived in the town since  and celebrated  years of marriage on May .Pat, , was born in Turton, Lancashire, and Ian, , is from Kilmarnock.The pair met at a dance in Kensington Town Hall while they were both working in London: Pat at Williams  Glynrsquos Bank and Ian for the civil service.The couple married in London on May ,  and have three children ndash Carol, Jan and Chris ndash and four grandchildren: Christopher, Lindsay, Art and Rudi.Ian is a keen walker and cyclist, often taking journeys from North Berwick to Kingston and Yellowcraig.Pat not only enjoys gardening and keeping fit but is also a sociable person who enjoys spending time with her family and friends.Daughter Carol said: ldquoOriginally we were going to book a meal at Osteria for extended family and friends but that was not to be.The couple celebrated instead with a tea party in their garden at Marmion Road.Carol said: ldquoBoth enjoyed a glass of champagne with scones on the day.

title: community-resilience-volunteers-dirleton-dunbar-east-linton-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonMIXED news has been delivered by the Dirleton Area Resilience Team .The group has been in charge of resilience efforts in the village during the coronavirus pandemic.It has had to move the community essentials larder from the villagersquos primary school to the nearby Castle Inn.David Tait, lead co-ordinator of DART, said it was a temporary measure and they were looking for new premises.The larder operates on Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, -pm.The booking line also remains the same as before, on  .David said: ldquoAlthough I am disappointed that we have had to move, this is a temporary solution and we will be looking to move again towards the end of June.Meanwhile, DART successfully launched its website last week and have been amazed by the response so far.Previously, they have been able to use the mailing lists of the Dirleton Village Associationand Dirleton Good Neighboursto distribute information.David added: ldquoNow that we have an established website and our own emailing system, we are establishing our own mailing list.ldquoResidents of the community who would like to continue to receive the DART newsletter and other information from DART are asked to send an email to news@dirletonresilience.org asking to join the mailing list.ldquoContact details will only be used for purposes of sending DART items and will not be shared with any other parties.ldquoIt should be noted, however, that DART newsletters will no longer be sent out using the DGN emailing lists.Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.dirletonresilience.orgDunbarDunbarTHE Dunbar resilience volunteers are asking for donations of unwanted laptops and computer tablets.The group, which was formed at the beginning of the lockdown period and has helped people in need by collecting shopping and prescriptions, last week launched the appeal for laptops and tablets to pass on to schoolchildren who are still home learning.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership , has been heavily involved in the volunteering efforts during the past twoand-a-half months.He said: ldquoI currently have about  devices ready for distribution via the schools, and will put out another appeal via Facebook later today.ldquoIt is important to reassure people that their personal data is not at risk when handing in an old laptop.ldquoAfter thorough external cleaning of the device, including the keyboard screen and touchpad, it is first of all booted from a USB stick then the entire hard drive is wiped to remove the old Windows installation and any personal data files.ldquoThe laptop is then reloaded with the Linux Mint operating system, together with all applications relevant for educational use.ldquoOccasionally some hardware TLC is needed to get things working properly.ldquoWhen this process is complete, the old laptops have a new lease of le and are perfectly useable for online lessons.ldquoThey can connect to the internet via wi-fithis is available in the household or via Bluetooth to a smartphonenot.ldquoMost come with worn out batteries so can only be used when connected to the mains.George, who is also a member of the townrsquos community council, said iPads could also be donated to the cause.The team have three already, which have been restored to factory settings and had all personal data removed.The devices will be handed to the townrsquos schools in the coming week and it will be up to staff to determine where they are most needed.Last week, George told the Courier: ldquoVery often, you find in a particular family they might have one laptop shared between several kids and all competing for it. ldquoIn one or two households, they might not have any devices at all that they can access the internet on.Contact detailsTo find out more, e-mail Dunbar.covid@gmail or call  .For more information, go to Dunbar and District Coronavirus Community Helpers at facebook groups  or Dunbar Community Council at facebook DunbarCommunityCouncilEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsDunpenderASSISTANCE remains on offer to anyone in need of help in East Linton and the surrounding villages.Judith Priest, chairwoman of Dunpender Community Council, which covers Tyninghame and Whitekirk, as well as East Linton, said very little had changed from a resilience point of view in the past seven days.Volunteers have given up their time to assist people in need during the coronavirus pandemic.Shopping has been collected, while prescriptions can also be picked up and, last month, special VE Day boxes were also delivered to some residents.Contact detailsThe community is being kept updated with information posted on the Tyninghame Village Hall website ndash www.tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk ndash as well as at www.eastlinton.uk.People can also call   or  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickA NEW project to provide computer tablets for residents at North Berwick care homes, to enable them to see and speak to relatives online, has been launched.Funding for the tablets has been provided by Foundation Scotlandrsquos Community Response Fund, which awarded a pound, grant to North Berwick Community Council to support the North Berwick Resilience fund, set up by community council chairwoman Judy Lockhart in March.The grant has been provided to enable residents in North Berwick care homes to maintain contact with family during isolation.Community council chairwoman Judy said: ldquoWe are delighted that the money is being put to such good use, enabling residents to communicate with their loved ones even in lockdown.ldquoBeing able to see them makes a huge dference.North Berwick Resilience Group has been working in partnership with North Berwick Rotary Club on the project, and the first two tablets have been presented to Astley House nursing home in the town.Rotary Club member Richard Rogers said Astley House was a pilot project and, depending on the results, it should be rolled out to other care homes.He said: ldquoIt is aimed at residents who have not been allowed to meet up with relatives due to the coronavirus restrictions. The tablets can also be used for other things such as playing music and watching videos.ldquoRotary has maintained contact with Astley House by providing links to interesting video programmes for residents, and will be following up to get feedback on how user-friendly and useful the staff working with residents are finding this project.ldquoThe club is also looking at an exciting initiative to allow volunteers to continue to serve the community post Covid ndash watch this space!Community council member Ian Watson sourced the first batch of Samsung tablets and the Rotary Club acquired the chargers.Meanwhile, North Berwick Resilience Group is continuing with its project aimed at supplying face coverings to those who need them most in the community.Volunteer Khlayre Cairney, who is co-ordinating the project, sayspeople have access to a sewing machine and would like to get involved in creating the coverings, they should get in touch by sending an email to community resilience@northberwickcommunitycouncil.org.ukContact detailsAs usual,residents need help with shopping or prescriptions they can go to www.nbresilience or phone  .

title: students-tour-preston-lodge-high-school-homes
story: Pupils are due toto Preston Lodge High School on August , following the summer holidays and coronavirus lockdown.Now, a short video has been created for those students leaving P behind and moving up to secondary school.The video, included in the schoolrsquos electronic newsletter PLus, allows people to look behind the doors of the Prestonpans secondary school.The newsletter notes: ldquoAs part of the launch of our P transition programme, we have provided all P students and their families with a virtual tour of our school building.ldquoMany thanks to Sarah Lusk [support for learning] for the great job that she has done.ldquoWe thought that some of our older PLers might enjoy revisiting the school that we are all missing!Watching the video allows potential pupils the chance to get their bearings and find dferent departments.Jonny Else, depute headteacher at the secondary school, told the Courier: ldquoIt is part of the transition programme because the pupils cannot physically be in the building just now.ldquoWe are trying to get them more comfortable about the surroundings and a lot of the feedback we have had from P pupils is they want to know where everything is in the school.A further video highlighting dferent departments is also being created.Mr Else added: ldquoThe building is probably more than double the size what they are used to and there are so many dferent rooms and departments.ldquoThe video is to make them feel as relaxed as they can in this dficult time.He added it was not just for future pupils at the school. Preston Lodge alumni can also refamiliarise themselves with their former secondary school.To view the video, go to www.edubuzz.org prestonlodge    p_transition_

title: musselburgh-sea-cadet-named-one-9-000-ordinary-heroes
story: In addition to being the officer-in-charge at Musselburgh Sea Cadets, Chris Gay, , is a busy ambulance control officer with the Scottish Ambulance Service.He said: ldquoI deal directly with Covid- patients as well as medical professionals across Scotland and my job is make sure the patients get the care they need as quickly as possible.ldquoI love being part of the service.ldquoEvery call is dferent and every call is a person needing help. I love to make sure they receive the first step along the way to getting the right patient care.He added: ldquoItrsquos helped my people skills which has also helped me within sea cadets.ldquoI was quite quiet when I started which is unusual for sea cadets.ldquoWhen you work with so many people, it brings you out of yourself and itrsquos definitely taken me out of my comfort zone.Eighty-five per cent of sea cadet activities at unit level are taking place lsquovirtuallyrsquo despite the loss of hugely popular inshore and offshore boating programmes, competitions and the international exchange programme.Sea Cadets remains an important part of many young peoplersquos lives with nearly , cadets nationwide. During lockdown, the impact of its volunteers on their lives hasnrsquot stopped, with a recent survey showing wide satisfaction with the lsquovirtualrsquo sea cadetsrsquo programme.Captain Phil Russell, RN, Captain of Sea Cadets, said Chris was one of the ldquoordinary heroes across the UK who was helping Sea Cadets offer a dferent kind of adventure to young people.As officer-in-charge he is holding weekly Zoom sessions and Google Classrooms to train sea cadets in a series of skills such as in first aid, cooking and engineering.Captain Russell said: ldquoSea Cadets are proud of our strong links with the Royal Navy but volunteers join us from all walks of le and no previous nautical experience is needed.ldquoWhen you start volunteering with us you can be assured of a warm welcome and an amazing experience as part of the sea cadet family.Musselburgh Sea Cadets also recently raised funds through crowdfunding to buy treats such as sweets, chocolates and small gts for hard-working frontline health care workers during the Covid- crisis.A major pound, refurbishment of TS Indefatigable, their South Street base, had also just got underway when the Covid- lockdown struck.Potential volunteers who want to join Sea Cadets can find their local unit by going to the website at www.sea-cadets.orgVolunteersrsquo Week takes place June - every year.Itrsquos a chance to celebrate and say thank you for the contribution millions of volunteers make across the UK.

title: community-resilience-volunteers-aberlady-cockenzie-port-seton-gullane-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Aberlady. Picture: Google MapsAberladyVOLUNTEERS are continuing to do what they can to offer support to vulnerable and elderly members of the community in Aberlady.Aberlady Resilience has dealt with about  requests for help during the coronavirus pandemic.Resilience group member Ian Malcolm told the Courier they continued to be there for people in need of assistance. He said: ldquoWe are not particularly aware of anybody having any particular problems.ldquoWe have got a fair number of volunteers and there are messages being delivered every day.ldquoIt is all small scale stuff.Contact detailsAnyone needing help should contact either Ian Malcolm on   or Sam Robertson on  . Further information is available online at www.facebook Aberlady-Resilience-Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience effort in Cockenzie and Port Seton continues to help those in need in the community, and is on the lookout for more dog walkers.The effort is being led by the local community council, whose chairman Bryan Hickman said that those who wish to volunteer as dog walkers should contact the emergency resilience number on  .Anyone who needs assistance of any kind is also asked to contact this number.As well as collecting prescriptions and helping with shopping, staff and volunteers at the Port Seton Centre have made and delivered food packages and hot meals.So far almost , meals have been handed out.The resilience team has also been supporting the work of the local school hubs, with crafts packs going out to families alongside breakfast packs.Lunch packs continue to be provided to children who would usually receive free school meals.People are reminded that the sports pitches at the Port Seton Centre remain closed, and fall under phase two of the Scottish Governmentrsquos plan to ease lockdown restrictions.In the past week, spaghetti bolognese cooking packs, including onions picked from the Seed-to-Plate initiative, have been delivered to families in the Preston Seton Gosford area .The PSG Area Partnership has thanked the East Lothian Council Connected Communities administration staff who helped to pay for  families to receive cooking packs for two weeks.A pantry at Port Seton Centre is open pm-pm MondayFriday for those needing food, toiletries or pet food.Those who wish to attend are asked to social distance and wait for a member of staff to assist them.Delivery enquiries can also be made by calling  .Contact detailsThose who require assistance of any kind are asked to call the resilience emergency number on  .Gullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneVOLUNTEERS throughout Gullane have vowed to continue offering services to people in need, despite lockdown restrictions easing.The Gullane Resilience Team has been working hard throughout the coronavirus pandemic to assist anyone in the village who is vulnerable.A spokesman for the group said that would be continuing, and told the Courier: ldquoWith Scotland entering stage one of the exit strategy, we will still be continuing with all our activities but at the same time planning for the changes required at each of the following stages, in addition to the effect on the pool of volunteers available.ldquoOnce again, our thanks go to the many volunteers who have given so much of their time.The pool of volunteers deal with referrals and requests for the uplt of prescriptions.Every Tuesday, from .am to .am, and on Fridays from noon to pm, in the village hall there is a ldquohub.The group spokesman said: ldquoWe have our food distribution, DVD, book and jigsaw exchange plus ious types of bread flours and yeast for sale for the bakers in the community.ldquoLorna Scott, Amy Irvine, Rachel Wallace and Sue Bryce have been very busy making weekly, themed craft packs which are freely available for children in the village and are proving very popular.ldquoFabric face coverings made by the Gullane Scrubbers are also available ndash with donations going towards the East Lothian Foodbank.Contact detailsFor more information, call   or email Gullanerteam@gmailInformation can also be found at www.gullanert and by searching on Facebook for Gullane RT.Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansPRESTONPANS Community Council chairperson Brian Weddell has appealed to people to stick to the lockdown guidelines, after a weekend which saw people travel from ldquofar and wide to East Lothianrsquos beauty spots.Brian said the community resilience team were working hard to ensure the most vulnerable residents are receiving support and supplies during the lockdown, and the actions of daytrippers over the weekend had left them concerned.He said: ldquoUnfortunately, many peoplersquos worst fears were confirmed over the weekend with East Lothian being inundated with daytrippers driving down the coast from far and wide.ldquoDespite the very clear messages being given last week by the Scottish Government and East Lothian Council that the lsquorelaxed lockdown measuresrsquo still included only travellingessential, staying home as much as possible, not travelling more than five miles from your local area, avoiding tourist and beauty spots ndash the East Lothian coast road was rammed with cars all weekend and the beaches packed.As one local Panner put it to me: lsquoFolk are just going mental and not listening to what the governments are saying.rsquoldquoThe last thing we all need after more than two months of strict lockdown measures is a second wave of infections that puts huge pressure on the NHS and frontline health and social care services, as well as the resilience volunteers.ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos lsquotesting and tracingrsquo strategy is now operational and people need to listen to the advicethey are asked to self-isolate."It is in their own interests and those of their family, friends and neighbours to stick to the rules.Last week was the busiest yet for the Pennypit Pantry, with , meals delivered over the course of the week.East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes, highlighted in last weekrsquos Courier, delivered  meals over the weekend.The community council also gave special thanks to Calum and Michelle Wilson who run The Goth pub and who have been providing breakfast packs to local families since the end of March.Brian said: ldquoThe Prestonpans resilience team are delighted to support this project as it is an additional resource providing lsquothe most important meal of the dayrsquo to local children.Contact detailsAny local businesses or anyone who wants to donate to any of the fantastic community-based projects can contact the resilience hotline telephone number   or email prestonpansresilience@gmail

title: dvla-announces-important-changes-driving-licences-set-expire
story: The announcement, made yesterday, aims tohelp drivers to make necessary journeys without having to geta new photograph to renew their licence.Normally, drivers are required to renew their photocard licence every ten years, and bus and lorry drivers every five years.A new EU regulation has now been introduced which means photocards that expire betweenFebruary  andAugust ,  will be automatically extended for a further seven months from the date of expiry.Drivers will be sent a reminder to renew before their seven-month extension ends.This extension applies to the photocard. If a driverrsquos entitlement to drive is due to expire and they wish to continue to hold a valid licence, they will need to renew this entitlement in the normal way.What have the DVLA said DVLA Chief Executive Julie Lennard said:ldquoThis extension will make it easier for drivers who need to update their photocard licence with a new photograph."This means as long as they have a valid licence, drivers will be able to continue to make essential journeys.ldquoThe extension is automatic so drivers do not need to do anything and will be sent a reminder to renew their photocard before the extension ends.The DVLArsquos online services to renew your driving licence and replace a driving licence are available for those drivers who need to renew their entitlement to drive or replace a lost or stolen licence.

title: coronavirus-make-face-mask
story: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed this was under consideration in her daily briefing yesterday, but stressed there is no timescale on when the wearing of one mightenforced across the country.Ms Sturgeon was keen to emphasise medical face masks should be prioritised for frontline workers and instead has encouraged Scots to make their own face coverings from home."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Sturgeon considering making face coverings mandatory in Scotland","description": "Nicola Sturgeon says she is considering making face coverings mandatory. The First Minister said the Government has not made a final decision whether to implement the policy.","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media AlflgpM poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests AlflgpM.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.eastlothiancourier video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "East Lothian Courier","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.eastlothiancourier sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Whether you are handy with a Singer or just want a quick fix, there are so many ways you can make sure you are protected.Heres our guide to dferent types and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.What do I need to make a face covering There are many dferent materials you can use to protect yourself and stop the spread of Covid- to those around you.This ranges from bandanas, to t-shirts, fabrics, to string. The important thing is you should be able to find most of these items in your home already.Think of this as a good chance to finally find a use for that t-shirt in the back of the cupboard youve been meaning to take to a charity shop for as long as you can remember.You dont need to be an expert in sewing machines to make your own face covering Well show you how to make some coverings in the next section, but here are some of the items you will need to make one:What are the dferent types of home-made face coverings and how can I make one The UK government advises washing your hands or using hand sanitiser before putting on and after taking off face coverings.You should also:The one with the bandanaOkay. Not many of us will have a spare bandana sitting around butyou do they are an easy way to make an effective covering.For this youll need: Elastic ties or hairpins, and your bandana. Thats it.Step one: Lay the cloth out flatStep two: Fold in halfStep three: Fold top third down, fold bottom up to meet itStep four: Thread through two elastic bandsStep five: Fold each side to the middle and tuck into the foldsThe one with the t-shirtHave a look in your cupboard. Wed bet you have at least one old t-shirt which either doesnt fit or looked more at home in a Wham video than .Well, now is the perfect time to say goodbye and recyle your old shirt for good.Heres what youll need: An old t-shirt, scissors, kitchen towel, pinsStep one: Draw pattern across arms and body of t-shirtStep two: Cut along patterns so you have two layers from front and back of t-shirtStep three: Pin one sideSteph four: Inset non-woven fabric material such as a paper towelStepfive: Pin other sideSteph six: Tie at back so it is tight across the nose and tight under the chinThe one that needs sewingThis is one for the wannabe sewing bees. Dust off that Singer and have a go and youll have an effective face covering in no time.Heres what youll need: A sewing machine, needle and thread, scissors, elastic, towel, fabricStep one: Cut two cloth rectangles cmxcmStep two: Place on top of each other, waysStep three: Fold over the top of the fabric .cm and stitch all the way acrossStep four: Fold the bottom up and stitch .cm inwards from the edge of either side - this will create a filter pocketStep five: Folder the shorter sides inwards about cm and stitch - leaving a gap to thread elasticStep six: Thread a cm piece of elastic through the hem on one side and tie the ends. Repeat on the other sideStep seven: Put kitchen paper inside as filterVisit here for more guidance from the UK Government.We have also used information from the Centre for Disease Control and Prevention .

title: column-easing-lockdown-restrictions-ruined-stupidity-others-says-msp
story: LAST weekend was the first of lsquophase onersquo of easing the lockdown, which now seems to have been with us forever.Many of us took the chance to see family face to face, albeit outside and at a distance, for the first time in many weeks.Others were able to enjoy golf, bowls or fishing at long last, eventhe clubhouse remained off limits.What a pity that some communities had any joy they might have felt in some easing of restrictions ruined by the stupidity of others who abused that progress.The countyrsquos coastal villages and other beauty spots were swamped with people heading for a day out and simply ignoring the advice not to travel more than five miles for leisure.Finding car parks and toilets closed, they parked, peed and worse without consideration, then left litter everywhere.The council has been caught between a rock and a hard place, instructed by the First Minister not to open car parks, andthey do facing accusations of encouraging the flouting of the rules. Yet chaos resulted.I know the council is discussing with government and COSLA how to respond. Police, traffic wardens and Countryside Rangers did their best but were overwhelmed.On Monday, the First Minister made clear thatthis continues we will go back into lockdown, and the guidance will be given the force of law but perhaps we should have done that first, and hopefully as we move into other phases the guidance will be better thought out, clearer and unambiguous.A further sign that we are not yet out of the woods was an inexplicable fall in numbers of Covid- tests.Further phases of leaving lockdown, such as school openings, depend on widespread community testing, and in parliament we continue to get no answers on why this is still not happening.There is still a real danger that the infection rate will rise again and more people will die unnecessarily.We all have a part to play. Please do follow the guidance to save lives.

title: primary-school-pupils-lead-whole-school-treasure-hunt-home

title: musselburgh-marlins-become-first-east-lothian-club-achieve-top-swim-benchmark
story: Already proud holders of a SwiMark certicate, received in , they have now been awarded SwiMark Plus in Scottish Swimmingrsquos accreditation scheme which provides a nationally recognised standard for clubs and swim schools.Head coach Danny Kirkham said: ldquoMusselburgh Amateur Swimming Clubis delighted to have been awarded Scottish Swimmingrsquos highest accreditation, SwiMark Plus.ldquoThis means that Scottish Swimming recognises MASC as a quality programme which is swimmer centred and strives to ensure we provide the best environment possible for our swimmers to reach their full potential.ldquoThis award shows MASC are leading the way in setting new standards for swimming in the community. Through the work undertaken, a development plan which spans the whole club will ensure we keep progressing and moving forward to ensure MASC remains strong and sustainable long into the future.The club has come a long way since its origins in , when swimmers used to hone their skills in the local harbour. The pool at Loretto School was used over the years before the club moved to Musselburgh Sports Centre after it opened in .A year ago, MASCrsquos management committee and coaches held a planning meeting with Scottish Swimming to establish the steps required to be completed in order to achieve SwiMark Plus.A small voluntary project group embarked on reviewing, revising and signing off the extensive SwiMark criteria before engaging in consultative activities across the club, implementing revised and new policies and procedures, analysing data and producing a four year development and action plan.Club president and project manager Gill Downie said: ldquoMany thanks to the small project team heavily involved in delivering this huge feat through endless hours of blood, sweat and tears. It really is a remarkable achievement during the transitional year following chairman Jack Calderrsquos death ndash illustrating MASCrsquos resilience, drive and passion to be recognised as a trusted leader within aquatics sport by offering exceptional all-encompassing swimming development programmes, coaching education tuition and volunteer training within the community. In addition, effective club management and robust financial review systems will ensure MASC is a viable family-friendly resource within East Lothian well into the future.Alan Reed, Scottish Swimmingrsquos regional swimming development manger , added: ldquoWith the committee and other members working hard to gain this award, they have shown that they are a really strong and sustainable club.ldquoA crucial part of the accreditation is the formation of a development plan ndash this ensures that the club is making consistent progress and looks towards the future.ldquoThe club has excellent structures that have been put in place through the process and this has been demonstrated by all the engagement and activity the club has continued through this recent period of change. It has been a pleasure working with the club and helping support them to gain their SwiMark Plus accreditation.The top benchmark is also held by East Lothian Swim Team which provides a performance training environment for countyrsquos top talent. The best swimmers from Musselburgh, Tranent and Haddington Amateur Swimming Clubs train together as a single composite team to achieve success at East District, Scottish National, British and International levels.

title: tim-tales-kings-elephant
story: This week is a story from India which I like, not least because the main character is my favourite animal an elephant.Irsquove loved elephants since early childhood. They are a giant of nature, yet also incredibly intelligent. They feel emotion like we do, in fact possibly more so as the emotional part of their brain is even more developed than that of humans.The old saying that ldquoan elephant never forgets is rooted in this fact. An elephantrsquos emotional intelligence comes from its ability to remember and recall distant memory. Like humans, an elephantrsquos way of being is mostly learned in early le, rather than just based on instinct.They are therefore highly sensitive creatures, influenced and affected by what they experience just as we are.Irsquove heard dferent versions of this tale, and here I have peppered it very slightly with my own style:Once, a king in ancient India owned an elephant. This royal elephant was the joy not just of the king, but also his people.The trainer would ride the elephant every day along the streets. She was a magnicent sight, and children would run out to wave and watch the elephant go by. The trainer took a dferent route each day so people in dferent neighbourhoods all had a chance to enjoy the spectacle.The people felt a real love and affinity for the elephant. Despite her size and strength, she was gentle and affectionate with the people. She would pat children carefully on their heads with her trunk and took care in where she walked.The elephant made people feel safe. More than once she had saved a child from drowning in the nearby river, or from a predator from the jungle. She was a sacred animal to the people.But then people began to notice a change in the elephantrsquos behaviour. She became aggressive and unpredictable. Instead of being patient with the children she knocked them out of her way with her trunk. Instead of being careful where she walked, she deliberately trampled on peoplersquos gardens.The trainer tried his best to control the elephant, but she seemed like a dferent animal. He couldnrsquot understand why she was behaving so dferently.It just got worse, until one day the elephant suddenly set off on a charge and rampaged through the streets, trumpeting loudly as she charged at the terried people, almost killing some of them.The king was horried and ordered the elephant to be confined to her stables. With dficulty she was finally brought under control and locked in.ldquoWhat is going on  asked the king to the trainer.ldquoI have no idea your majesty he replied, ldquoitrsquos asshe is a dferent elephant.ldquoPerhaps the elephant is ill in some way  suggested one of the kingrsquos advisors. But the vet found nothing physically wrong.Then the trainer suggested asking an old man who lived in the jungle as ldquohe is known for his wisdom in understanding animals, perhaps he will know what the cause of this is.So the king sent a messenger and the old man came to the royal palace.ldquoCan you help  asked the king.The old man asked to be left alone with the elephant for a while.When he ed he looked at the king and said: ldquoWhatever is wrong is something that cannot be seen. I must spend some time with the elephant to understand what is troubling her.And so the old man decided to watch over the elephant that night. He smeared himself in mud to mask his scent and hid in a corner of the stable.It was late evening when he heard voices.A group of men had entered the stables from a small side door. They were a gang of murderers. They were using the royal elephant stable as a place to meet and plan their activities. And in so doing they recounted stories of their deeds.Their leader was a man with a cold and ruthless heart. He told stories about his le and deeds, of how hersquod murdered and tortured people he didnrsquot like. Members of his gang laughed and shared their tales too, likewise full of hatred and cruelty.The elephant slumbered as these tales were told, but they were unknowingly heard by her. When the elephant woke the following morning, the tales of hate and violence still swirled in her mind.The old man went to the king.ldquoYour majesty, there are two things you must do to cure the elephant.ldquoThe first is to remove the murderers who meet in the stables at night. The second is you must find the kindest people, who live their lives with love and understanding. Then ask them to meet at night in the stable as the elephant sleeps and tell each other stories from their lives tales of love and understanding. If you do this, then the elephant will be cured.The king looked bemused.ldquoI will most certainly remove the murderers, he said, ldquobut are you saying that stories will cure the elephant ldquoYes, your majesty, replied the old man, ldquobut the right stories. You see we are made from the stories we hear.He went on: ldquoIf we constantly hear tales of hatred and violence then those stories paint our vision of le with fear, loathing and cruelty.ldquoButwe mostly hear tales of love and understanding, then our mind is coloured with kindness for others, and for ourselves.ldquoWe are affected by the stories we hear, evenwe donrsquot realise we have been listening to them.ldquoYour elephant was unknowingly listening to tales of hatred and killing every night as she slept. So her mind was filled with hate and distrust her vision of the world changed and so did her behaviour.ldquoIf she hears good stories then she will eventually become her kind self again.The king nodded in understanding and agreed to act on this. Within a few weeks the elephantrsquos behaviour had changed for the better.ldquoYou are indeed wise in the ways of elephants, the king said to the old man.ldquoThe truth in this is not just for elephants, the old man replied.ldquoPeople are like your elephant the stories they hear will paint their world and affect how they live in it.The king nodded once again.ldquoMy job is done, said the old man, ldquoI will nowto the forest.ldquoBy the way, your elephant will have a calf, and her calf must hear good stories too.ldquoHow can I pay you for your wisdom  asked the king.The old man thought for a moment, then said: ldquoBe a king who tells good stories tales of kindness and understanding. And be a good listener to the stories told by your people.ldquoThen you will be a truly great leader and your kingdom will flourish and be a happier place.ldquoIf you do that, it will be my greatest reward.

title: strawberry-moon-2020-time-see-skies-uk
story: The Strawberry Moon coincideswith summer solstice once every  years when the moon is situated on the opposite side of the Earth as the Sun - whichfully illuminates its round shape.Unfortunately, despite its fruity name, the moon may notappear in warm colours as we would expect.The lunar event got its name fromNative American tribes, who used the moon to help them indicate when fruit would be ripened.What does NASA say about the Strawberry Moon As described by NASA: ldquoThe Maine Farmers Almanac first published Indian names for the full moons in the s.ldquoAccording to this almanac, the full moon in June or the last full Moon of spring is known as the Strawberry Moon, a name universal to just about every Algonquin tribe.ldquoThe name comes from the relatively short season for harvesting strawberries in northeastern North America.The Strawberry Moon has also been referred to as the Hot Moon.So, when can I see it You can expect to see the spectacular lunar event at about .pm BST tonight .According to the Royal Greenwich Observatory in London, the Strawberry Moon will last for up to three orfour days.

title: black-lives-matter-donate-help-get-diverse-books-primary-schools
story: The fund -which has raised over pound, since it was created on Wednesday, June  - aims to help black, Asian and minority ethnicstudents to feel represented by their school libraries.The initiative was inspired by protests that have taken place across the world calling for justice after the death of George Floyd, who died in police custody in Minneapolis on May .Who created the fund Scott Emmons, who created the fund, told the PA news agency:ldquoTherersquos a lack of books in primary schools where not only can teachers teach the white students about these issues, but also the BAME students are severely under-represented in the books that they have."Mr Emmons, , who lives in Wanstead, added: ldquoI went to the protest on Wednesday in Hyde Park and came away feeling so energised. There were so many people in Hyde Park who caredhellip there are so many people wanting to change, wanting to help.What books will the fund help The fund will put bundles into libraries, which include  books for children aged three to , and include the stories of Nelson Mandela and Rosa Parks.In , a report from the Centre for Literacy in Primary Education revealed that over the course of the year, only  per centof childrenrsquos books published in the UK had a BAME hero.These books allow those dficult conversations to startldquoIf therersquos no literature there to start this conversation, and white teachers find it dficult to speak about, then these are the tools that allow you to have that conversation, Mr Emmons told PA.Mr Emmons explained that he would like the initiative to go further than the GoFundMe page he has created, with the hope of schools tailoring the books to fit their own schoolsrsquo needs.He said: ldquoThe idea for this campaign is not to pay for everyonersquos books, itrsquos to be that driving force and that spark to put pressure on schools to get these books in and allow the children in their classrooms to see themselves represented.ldquoIt isnrsquot just a case of a lack of fundinghellip a lot of the schools do have the funding theyrsquore just not prioritising correctly. Theyrsquore not purchasing the right books.How can I make a donation To see the pagersquos donations, visit: http:gofundme f help-our-children-read-about-race

title: tell-difference-symptoms-hay-fever-covid-19
story: It comes as the weather gets warmer and summer approaches, with hay fever sufferers having to cope with more pollen in the air.But could coughing be a sign of hayfever, and as coronavirus sticks around, how can you tell it apart from allergy symptoms Heres what you need to know.What is hay fever Hay fever, also known as seasonal allergies, tends to flare up between late March and September according to the NHS, as this is when itrsquos warm, humid, windy and when pollen count is at its highest.Healthline says: ldquoWhen your body is exposed to allergens, it releases histamines.ldquoHistamines are meant to protect you from harm, but they can also cause the allergy symptoms that make some seasons uncomfortable.Hay fever and its symptoms are not contagious for those around you.Is coughing a symptom of hay fever Hay fever comes with a lot of dferent symptoms, one of which is a cough.Other symptoms include:The NHS says thatyou also suffer from asthma, you might get confused about what their symptoms mean.Most hay fever sufferers are affected from childhood, and will probably be expecting their symptoms every year around the same time.If yoursquove never had hay fever before, and you suddenly begin experiencing symptoms, itrsquos understandable that this might cause concern.Patient Info says: ldquoAround one in five people with hay fever get symptoms for the first time over the age of , so therersquos no reason to assume an adultrsquos symptoms canrsquot be caused by hayfever just because theyrsquove never had it before.Marc Donovan, chief pharmacist for more than an hour, or three or more coughing episodes in  hours.Boots Pharmacy released an graphic which shows the dference between hay fever symptoms and coronavirus symptoms, and included information like:How do I treat hay fever There is currently no cure for hayfever, but there are things you can do to help your symptoms according to the NHS, which includes:A pharmacy can also help title: glasgow-set-enter-lockdown-phase-2-next-week---changes
story: The First Minister saidthat, "at least in part", more of the coronavirus lockdown measures will be eased on at the next formal review on June .At the Scottish Governmentdaily briefing, Ms Sturgeonsaid: "I am optimistic that, ten days from now at the next formal review, we will be able to move, at least in part, into the next phase of our routemap out of lockdownwith more inidual freedoms restored and more businesses able to open up and operate again."But that depends on each and every one of us, so please, please, stick with it for now."It comes as figures shows for a second day in a row there were no new deaths reported overnight in Scotland.This comes with the message of caution, with fewer deaths usuallyrecorded over the weekends.Nicola Sturgeon optimistic of entering Phase  next weekWhile not all of these may take place, these are some of the measures set out in the routemap out of lockdown for Phase .Seeing friends and familyFrom June , people in Scotland may be able to meet people from other households indoors for the first time - while maintaing physical distancing and hygeine measures.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside.Shopping and pubsFrom Phase , the Scottish Government says pubs and restaurants CAN open outdoor spaces such as beer gardens - so long as social distancing measures can be maintained.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.Previously closed small retail units can also reopen - again with the underlying pin of physical distancing.SportsThe resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is currently planned for Phase .Likewise,sports courts and playgrounds may also be able toreopen from this date.However gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .Weddings and worshipIt is hoped that under Phase , marriages and civil partnerships can take place in Scotland with minimal number of attendees.The routemap also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .TransportPeople may be able to drive locally for leisure under the Phase  routemap.Public transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab andresearch facilities.The contruction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .There can also be a relaxation of restriction on housing moves.Scotlands route-map out of coronavirus lockdownhttps:t.co LNSqkNz pic tjtWu

jobs are on the line after the UK arm of retailer Victorias Secret collapsed into administration.Around  stores are at risk after the lingerie retailer called in Deloitte for a light touch title: lockdown-need-wear-bra
story: For many, this means saying goodbye to a slower way of le and easing back into the grind of a daily commute. For me  Its ing to the shackles of wearing a bra.If you dont wear a bra typically ndash and I appreciate that large swathes of the population have no need for one ndash then it is perhaps dficult to fathom the feeling of liberation that not wearing a form-fitting undergarment brings.I realise the bra has powerful political connotations and to avoid wading into that particular quagmire let me state: this is all about comfort and sloth.How you feel about bras largely depends on how you view breasts: ornamental or utilitarian  Those in the former camp tend to spend a lot of their hard-earned cash on fancy underwear and outfits that showcase their assets.: Susan Swarbrick: Ah, garden centres how do I love thee  Let me count the waysThe second category is typied by arriving home of an evening ndash or at least we did when offices were still a thing ndash to cast off both coat and bra in quick succession, sighing in relief as blood flow again reaches the welts on each shoulder where the straps have been digging in.During lockdown, the only times I have worn a bra is while exercisingor on a video call with colleagues .More recently, I have worn a bra when receiving guests in the garden, putting it on with all the lacklustre enthusiasm of a Victorian lady being shoehorned into her corset.It is a necessary evil when outdoors, as I discovered to my peril during a conversation with a neighbour over the garden wall.The upshot was I had to keep my arms strategically crossed over my chest the entire time which made me look far more defensive when discussing encroaching tree roots than I genuinely was.An underwire snapped clean in half the other day which I like to think was an act of rebellion but is more likely a reflection on the poor nick of an ageing fleet of brassieres.: Susan Swarbrick: Theof s-style holidays  Count me inNor are bras my only nemesis. I feel the same way about the jeans languishing in my wardrobe. I have visions of having to douse myself in grease simply to coax them above the knees. At this juncture, I doubt even Geoff Capes in his heyday could summon sufficient strength to help fasten the button. Hey ho.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: five-alternative-fathers-day-experiences-lockdown
story: A day trip, family get together, a meal at dads favourite might have been on the cards to celebrate Fathers Day, but with our choices restricted this year due to lockdown there are some great alternatives out there.Your dad might be just as happy, or long for, playing a solitary round of golf at his local course or sitting by the riverbank waiting for his catch of the day, but might also want to come together with loved ones to celebrate his special day.From small garden gatherings, to Zoom parties, or virtual museum tours or a local stroll, we bring you the best ideas to make it a Fathers Day to remember.Virtual Museum TourWhile all their museums remain closed due to coronavirus, the National Museum of Scotland have opened their virtual doors for people to enter a world of discovery.Their website gives you the chance to explore their collections and discover more about amazing objects through stories, films, games and resources.There is the chance to delve into our animated adventures and find out more about le in ancient Egypt, learn some Mandarin. Watch videos on a day in the le of an ancient Egyptian priestPriests occupied a unique place in ancient Egyptian society. Find out what they did every day and why in this short animated film. Created for the Discovering Ancient Egypt gallery.There is also the chance to The East Asian CalendarThe East Asian calendar uses a unique system to measure and mark the passing of time. Discover the twelve animals in the calendar and find out what your animal sign is. Created for the East Asia gallery.For more information go to www.nms.ac.uk national-museum-of-scotland If you fancy going a little further afield in your virtual discovery why not take a look at the Louvre in Paris.Activities on offer at the online Louvre include:- One minute in a museum- YouTubers at the Louvre- Mona Lisa VR experience-  years of history- A closer look at Louvre artworksOr you can take a virtual tour of Founding Myths: From Hercules to Darth Vader.The Louvrersquos Petite Galerie first exhibition tells how illustrators, sculptors, painters, puppeteers, filmmakers, and musicians around the world have drawn inspiration from myths, given them form, and brought them to le.Local family walkNow we are allowed to exercise more than once a day and can meet up with another household, a walk near your home could be the ideal gathering.Check out the Ramblers Scotland website to find walks close to home of dfering levels. A great way to enjoy daily local exercise is to try one of their  free mapped Medal Routes short, circular walks in every local authority area in Scotland.Medal Routes are downloadable maps for short, fun circular walks of ,  or  minutes. They are available in every local authority area across Scotland and there are over  walking routes to choose from.The organisation has been working hard to help inspire people to keep active during lockdown - including via through their #RoamSweetHome campaign.If you are giving the Medal Routes a go in your local area during your daily exercise, they are looking for you to share photos or videos from your Medal Route walk by using the #RoamSweetHome hashtag or tagging us on social media.For more information got to www.ramblers.org.uk scotland.aspxGo for a bike rideSales of bikes have soared during lockdown with many shops now having waiting lists after being completely sold out. Transport Secretary Michael Matheson recently confirmed cycling levels are % higher compared with the lockdown baseline, while Cycling Scotlandrsquos automatic cycling counters at  spots around the country revealed remarkable results, with one in Dunfermline recording an increase of % since lockdown.There are a number of family routes to explore without going too far from home. National Cycle Network routes in Scotland run through many areas of outstanding natural beauty, taking in vast forests, iconic castles, shimmering lochs, tranquil glens and spectacular coastlines. The routes provide a unique snapshot of the countryrsquos rich history whilst also connecting all of Scotlands major cities.There are approximately , milesof National Cycle Network routes in Scotland, including  miles of traffic-free routes which use a mix of railway path, canal towpath, forest road, shared-use path, segregated cycle lanes and redetermined rural footways.More information can be found at www.sustrans.org.ukVirtual park discoveryWhile travelling too far afield might just be a distant dream at the moment, we will have to make do with exploring some parts of the great outdoors from our armchairs.Prepare to feel slightly dizzy on the virtual tour for Calornias Yosemite National Park. Virtual Yosemite is a groundbreaking interactive tour of one of Americarsquos most popular and spectacular natural environments.
