title: fiona performs virtual commitment ceremony
story: First Minister Arlene Foster fears Brexit trade talks ‘are not going particularly well’Nurse ‘kicked in face’ and ‘two paramedics threatened’ by man receiving treatment in NI hospitalNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsPeopleFiona performs virtual commitment ceremonyA Co Down woman, who retrained as a civil celebrant after  years in banking, recently performed her first virtual ‘commitment ceremony’ for a couple whose wedding was postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic.By Helen McGurkMonday, th June , : pm""Fiona Solomon performing the commitment ceremony from her homeFiona Solomon, who worked for the Ulster Bank for four decades, before leaving last October, said she was ‘‘thrilled’’ when she was contacted by a couple in London, who had been forced to postpone their ‘physical’ wedding, but already had their wedding rings engraved with the date, June .The groom-to-be, Edward, decided to mark the day with a virtual ‘commitment ceremony’.Initially he had planned to keep the whole thing a secret from his bride-to-be, Jenner, but Fiona, who runs Perfect Day Ceremonies By Fiona, advised him it might be better to make her aware of the plans, so she could make the most of the occasion with an appropriate dress and make-up.Fiona worked with the groom to design the ceremony script and the bride heard it for the first time during the Zoom event – along with their  virtual guests. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...The wedding took place in the garden of the groom’s parents - which is now possible in England under the Covid- restriction - and Fiona delivered the service from her home in Ballygowan. What we are trying to deliver is a minimal viable product to keep product moving, to keep food on shelves on January ,  – that’s how serious it is,” he said. reopen from Tuesday, May , but by appointment only.The booking system is to help comply with social distancing regulations, protecting residents and staff.Residents will be able to book an appointment from am on Thursday, May  via the Vale councilrsquos website.There will be  slots released for the next fortnight of bookings, beginning May  -  slots at Atlantic Trading Estate and  for Llandow.Any resident undertaking a journey to a HWRC within the Vale must comply with the current Government guidance and adhere to the social distancing measures that are in place to ensure safe operation and use of the centres.To begin with, only cars will be permitted access to the HWRC on Atlantic Trading Estate, Barry, and at Llandow.It will not be possible to provide access or appointment for trailers or vans at this time.Due to current demand, initially the council will be only be issuing one appointment slot per household, per month until further notice.Residents are asked to only make a bookingit is absolutely necessary, due to the sitesrsquo reduced capacity, and to arrive no earlier than five minutes before their allocated time to avoid any unnecessary queuing.The guidelines state that before visiting, residents must sort their waste or recycling appropriately to minimise the time at the site and residents must provide proof of residency eg driving licence or utility bill and display this in their windscreen while waiting to enter the site.Residents must follow on-site safety signs and guidance and residents should only exit their car when advised to do so by a member of site staff.Staff will be unable to provide assistance with lting or sorting so it is important to ensure all waste and recycling is manageable.Residents are also reminded thatthey do not respect social distancing or are abusive to staff they will be asked to leave site.It is important to remember that fly-tipping is a crime and leaving items outside the gates of a HWRC, on the street or in parks, woodlands and fields may result in a fixed penalty notice of up to pound being issued or even prosecution.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Cllr Peter King said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank residents for the assistance they have provided by storing items they wish to dispose of until now.ldquoUnfortunately, the period during which our household waste recycling centres were closed means there is now a backlog to clear, which is why we need a strict booking system until demand s to normal.ldquoWe appreciate this may cause some inconvenience but href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA PHOTOGRAPHER who has been able to work since the coronavirus lockdown has taken to the streets to capture le on the inside.Mum-of-one, Katrina Dimech is normally a photographer and videographer and teacher at Shutter Hire Kids Photography Club, but instead she decided to use her skills to raise money for the charity - Annarsquos Rescue Centre, in Cardf, from where she got her cat, Rocky.Miss Dimech, , of Penarth, took portraits of families stood on their doorsteps locally as a personal project, on Friday May .And she hopes to stage an exhibition when conditions allow.She said: ldquoI had lost all motivation.ldquoMy camera had been sitting in a bag unused for eight weeks and I was getting far too used to sitting in my pyjamas all day.ldquoThe aim was to capture this strange moment in history and to be able to do what I love - get out and take photographs while following government guidelines.ldquoI havenrsquot been able to work since March and photography is a huge part of my lestyle and happiness.ldquoI have been able to create beautul memories for these families.ldquoBack in March our family adopted a beautul family cat, Rocky, from Annarsquos Rescue Centre in Rumney, she said. ldquoWe were amazed to discover how much work this charity was doing in rescuing, rehabilitating, caring for, and rehoming cats and kittens.ldquoI realised that I could use this opportunity to raise some money for the charity by combining my doorstep photography project as a fundraiser."Donations were not compulsory.ldquoDuring lockdown this money is very much needed to feed the surplus cats that currently canrsquot be rehomed due to vets not neutering at this time, but also to help towards any upkeep or vets bills.ldquoMyself and my partner visited  homes beginning at am and finishing at :pm.ldquoWe met some amazing families and thoroughly enjoyed our day out.ldquoWe have plans to attempt one more session in Dinas Powys, Sully, and Barry.She said: ldquoWhen I started the project I was worried that I wouldnrsquot find much to photograph and that it would be dficult to find inspiration on someonersquos doorstop.ldquoI was wrong.ldquoEach family has a very dferent dynamic and portrait photography is all about allowing dferent personalities shine through.ldquoThe images were intended to be natural, raw, and a reflection of the times and I feel that I have achieved that outcome with the help of those who took part.Miss Dimech and her partner allowed  minutes for each household.ldquoIt was amazing to meet so many new faces and to catch up with some of my previous clients," she said. ldquoEach household was extremely thankful and it was a blessing to have that social interaction that most of us have all been craving.ldquoWorking with people is what I do best.ldquoI am a chatterbox who thrives on social interaction.ldquoEach family had a dferent story to tell, some were still working, furloughed, bored or enjoying lockdown.ldquoI met animals, children, grandparents, parents, it was title: welsh government resilience plan supports education over s
story: The plan helps ensure that learners are supported throughout the coronavirus pandemic.It is aimed at education for learners aged  and over, including further and higher education, apprenticeships, employability and adult learning.The plan identies the priority groups most in need of support and sets out the expectations of how education providers and the Welsh Government will work together in response to covid- and how key decisions will be communicated.Since education providers in Wales closed for face-to-face learning on March , colleges and universities have moved to remote learning, delivering online lectures, tutorials and reviews, as well as ensuring support for more vulnerable learners continues.The plan is ided into three phases ndash the current lsquorescuersquo phase is focused on ensuring education providers have immediate security of funding and arrangements for learning in place this academic year the lsquoreviewrsquo phase plans for potential changes this autumn and the lsquorenewrsquo phase will put arrangements in place for the remainder of the academic year -.The plan identies learners for whom the coronavirus is likely to cause the most disruption, including Year  and , and vocational learners who need to access colleges or workplaces to complete their courses.The Welsh Government has increased online resources for post- through its Hwb , with distance learning resources available for both learners and providers.The Resilience Plan follows the publication of the continuity of learning plan for schools, lsquoStay Safe. Stay Learningrsquo, published last month.Education minister Kirsty Williams has also announced that pound.m of capital funding, part of the Secircr Cymru programme, will be used to invite applications from Welsh universities to submit novel research proposals that could contribute to or boost the advancement of research that impacts covid-.Ms Williams said: ldquoThe coronavirus has presented huge challenges for both students and education providers, in both the immediate and the longer term.ldquoThis Resilience Plan will provide a clear focus so we can work together with our education partners to overcome these challengesldquoThis plan will complement our continuity of learning plan for schools, lsquoStay Safe. Stay Learningrsquo, but recognises the greater levels of autonomy and ersity of education and training provided by the post- sector.ldquoOur colleges, universities and training providers are critical to the national response to the coronavirus and the rebuilding of the economy. We are committed to doing all we can to support them.Minister for economy, transport and North Wales, Ken Skates said: ldquoWe do not only want to bounce back from this pandemic, but to build back better by creating a national economy which sees employment, wealth and prosperity sp equally across Wales.ldquoThe post- education sector will be crucial to this.ldquoAs we shape our recovery from the impacts of coronavirus, we are committed to doing all we can to provide a strong foundation for those looking for employment, learners, trainees and apprentices to flourish in the future.ldquoThis incredibly challenging period has already highlighted the talent, commitment and incredible resilience of training and learning providers in supporting iniduals here in Wales.ldquoItrsquos efforts like these that will help ensure we emerge from this crisis stronger than ever. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new app provide specialist advice gps seconds
story: The Consultant Connect app has been fast-tracked for use in NHS Wales to help deal with the covid- outbreak and support primary care in the long term to offer better advice and guidance to patients.By accessing speedy advice the new app will help prevent unnecessary hospital admissions and referrals and ensure that those needing hospital treatment are managed accordingly.The core service, being rolled out across Wales, gives clinicians access to specialists in respiratory medicine, cardiology, diabetes, palliative care and acute medicine for covid.Health Boards can also add access to a range of local advice that is appropriate to their patientsrsquo needs.A GP or other clinician accesses the service either by dialling a phone number or using the Consultant Connect app.After choosing a speciality from a menu they are connected with a specialist in an average of  seconds.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am very pleased we are able to start rolling out the Consultant Connect in NHS Wales."This will help to support primary care to determine the right treatment for their patients.ldquoRight now it will save crucial time for health care professionals and reduce the amount of hospital visits needed by patients, at a time when our NHS is facing extra pressure.ldquoIn the long-term the use of this technology is an important part of our plan for the future of health and social care,"A Healthier Wales."Making the most of technology is vital to us building a modern health and social care service, in which care is delivered closer to home. article_url   content_id one of his articles that such a progressive town as Penarth was without an operatic and dramatic society, writes Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Societypresident, Mary Gardner.The response to his outcry was quickly taken up and within three weeks the Penarth Operatic Society was formed.The Societyrsquos first production was Gilbert  Sullivanrsquos Iolanthe, played at The Hippodrome which later burnt down, and what a glittering opening evening it must have been as the audience wore evening dress.The review featured next day read, ldquoBrilliant Initial Performance.More newsVale council issues warning over the use of parksFines increased for coronavirus lockdown breachesMarie Curie Great Blooming Tea Party goes virtualA few years later in , the drama section came into being and with it a new title of the Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Society, known affectionately as PODS.Since then PODS has progressed down through the decades with many highlights along the way.One being in  when PODS presented that great musical, The King And I, which won the premier prize at the Waterford International Festival, for which the company received a beautul Waterford crystal vase.The Town Council held a reception to honour the Society at the Paget Rooms, and James Callaghan, the local MP, paid his tribute to PODS saying it ldquoadded lustre and brought culture to Penarth.Another landmark was the play, Dear Octopus, by Dodie Smith produced for PODS th anniversary celebrations.One of our most challenging and exciting shows was Cabaret in , which won the National Operatic  Dramatic Associationrsquos award for Best Production and Best Stage Management and Technical presentation.More recently in , to honour and pay tribute to the many men who gave their lives in World War One, PODS presented the very special play, Last Man Standing, which also won a NODA award for Best Drama.In , PODS decided to do pantomime, and this has been a greatly gratying and popular addition to the companyrsquos output.Itrsquos wonderful to see children in the cast having on-stage experience, and then those children in the audience, perhaps for the first time, enjoying and loving live theatre.PODS is a very busy Society putting on four shows a year, a musical, two plays and a pantomime.Mrs Gardner said: ldquoThis year, sadly and very upsettingly after much hard work by all involved, the covid- virus struck as PODS had just set-up at the Paget Rooms ready for its run of Goodnight Mister Tom, only to be told the venue would be shut down next day.ldquoSince January, the Society had also been rehearsing for its May musical, The Full Monty, and that too has had to be cancelled.       ,params: .pushldquoNevertheless, when this terrible emergency is over the company will put on these two productions sometime in the future. ldquoPODS is proud of its achievement in giving much pleasure and entertainment to the local community with its first-class shows over the last  years, and its goal is to make its centenary in  with the help of its faithful audiences, friends and patrons.PODS is always ready to welcome new members, but at the moment it cannot meet or rehearse due to the covid- restrictions.It might be some time before restrictions are lted on groups being able to rehearse together, or audiences allowed back in theatres, meanwhile PODS members keep in touch title: penarth esplanade sees surge visitors temperatures soar
story: Pictures and videos appeared on social media on Monday of groups of people sitting on the benches along the seafront, and groups of people gathering along the front.Currently, lockdown measures are still in place in Wales, and friends and families are not allowed to meet.More News:Tribute paid to Llandough Hospital nurse following her death from covid-Vale of Glamorgan Camera Club show Facebook their best spring picturesCoronavirus: New risk assessment in Wales for BAME peopleThe Welsh Government regulations state ldquoyou can only exercise alone or with a member of your household.South Wales Police did not discloseany people had been issued with a fine for breaking lockdown, but a spokesman said ldquoOur approach is to engage, explain and encourage people to follow the regulations.ldquoWe only apply [a Fixed Penalty Notice] as a last resort.ldquoItrsquos a matter for the inidual to ensure they follow the regulations.Some Penarth residents said they were concerned by the number of people along the seafront on Monday.Melanie Regan, , said she didnrsquot feel safe to walk along the seafront with her husband due to the number of people there.ldquoIt is so busy out there we donrsquot even walk out there, she said. ldquoThe bank holiday was packed, but it is not just the bank holidays.ldquoWith the amount of traffic and cars parked, itrsquos not just local people either.ldquoWe donrsquot feel safe going out there.Michelle Crow, from Penarth, said: ldquoWhile I was on my daily exercise walk with my dogs it felt like Windsor Road into Penarth was quite busy considering we are supposed to be in lockdown.However, other residents said the number of people at the seafront was not more than expected and everyone was following the guidance.Mary Taylor, from Penarth, said: ldquoWe were having our exercise along the promenade on Sunday.ldquoYes, most seats were occupied, there were people stood in between but on the whole they were s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE RNLI in Wales has reacted to the Welsh Governmentrsquos plans for easing lockdown with an important safety warning.The Governmentrsquos changes, from Monday, June , will limit people to staying local and not generally travel more than five miles to reduce the risk of the coronavirus spreading.People from two dferent households in the same local area will be permitted to meet up as long as they are outdoors, and they maintain strict social distancing.The lesaving charity has called for the public to stay safe.RNLI lesaving manager, Matt Crofts said: ldquoAfter a warm spring coupled with the easing of a lockdown which has seen many of us unable to visit our local beaches, we expect many people to be eager to hit the coast.ldquoThe changes to Government guidance does not mean our coasts are safe.ldquoThe dangers that have always been there remain.ldquoWe ask those who are local to beaches to continue to be aware of the inherent dangers.ldquoOur strong advice to the Welsh public, who are not local to a beach, is to follow the Welsh Government guidance to meet outdoors and exercise locally and not to travel to the coast.ldquoAir temperatures may be warming up but the sea temperature remains consistently chilly all year, jumping or falling into cold water or spending longer periods than normal submerged in the water can lead to, potentially fatal, cold water shock.Water safety lead for the RNLI in Wales, Chris Cousens urged people to remember the safety advice.He said: ldquoStay in familiar surroundings and follow the Welsh Government advice.ldquoDo not put yourself, your family and emergency services at risk by taking risks or assuming it lsquowonrsquot happen to yoursquo.ldquoIf you do see someone at risk call  and ask for the coastguard.A high proportion of calls for the RNLI in Wales are to those who have been to people cut off by the tide, including during the lockdown period.Some parts of Wales have among the highest tidal range in Europe.A beach that was clear yesterday at pm might be completely covered in sea at the same time today.Mr Cousens said: ldquoIf you are heading out for a coastal walk, make sure it is safe before you go.ldquoAlways check the tide times and conditions before you set off and while out, be aware of your surroundings and keep an eye on the tide direction.ldquoAsk for local advice and look out for safety signs.ldquoAlways carry a means of calling for help and know to call  and ask for the coastguardyou or someone  is at risk.The RNLI is working to start a leguard service on several beaches in Wales and is in discussion with the Welsh Government, local authorities, landowners, and other partners.At present there are no RNLI leguards on beaches in Wales. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey Sian from the MS Society Cymru said: ldquoThis really is an amazing donation and your support will allow us to continue to provide vital services for people affected by MS and to invest in groundbreaking medical research."To top off the evening of celebration the girls surprised everyone with some jaw-dropping performances by the incredible Valley Boys, a professional tribute act of west end singers dedicated to the Jersey Boys. The evening was a huge success and was enjoyed by all who were present.Miss Laity said: ldquoItrsquos hard to believe that as we reflect a year on, that things are currently so dferent for all of us but hopefully not for much longer.ldquoWhen the government announced all businesses were to close to protect society due to the covid- pandemic, it raised a lot of distress and uncertainty for many businesses, Beauty Within of Penarth included.But during the lockdown period, the pair have been - in line with ongoing government advice - been things in place to ensure they are ready towhen the go-ahead is given for the business to re-open.All existing and new clients will be assured of the usual warm welcome to the salon that previously existed.Both therapists have completed the Barbicide story: The radio station has launched the ldquoWersquoll Meet Again campaign for listeners to get in touch and share a message for an older person in their lives that they are currently unable to be with due to the virus restrictions.These touching messages will be played out by the station for the recipients to hear. However, the charity is also keen to stress that not all older people are fortunate enough to have family and friends and thatrsquos why the work of Age Connects is so vital, even more so now.Nona Hexter, who runs the charityrsquos Senior Health Shop on Holton Road in Barry said: ldquoFor so many years we have been here for older people to pop in for information, advice and have a cuppa and chat with their friends and us too."It is tough not being able to be there in person for all of the vulnerable older people that we know but staff and volunteers are ensuring we are still here at the end of the phone, helping with shopping and in any way we can within safety guidelines.Karen Steele from Age Connects said: ldquoIn the first seven weeks of lockdown, we received , incoming calls for information, advice and support and in almost all cases we have managed to provide support or signpost people onwards."The charity is urging the general public and local businesses to ldquohelp us help to keep older people safe, well and reassured at this dficult time by making a donation to support its work at grass roots level where it is making a vital dference.A donation of just pound will help the charity make reassuring telephone calls. pound will help support staff and volunteers get shopping for vulnerable older people.If you are an older person needing support at this time, or know s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentCHANGES to advice for people shielding from coronavirus are being introduced from Monday, June .People who have been shielding can now take exercise outdoors and meet people from another household, as long as it takes place outdoors.There are two changes to the advice for this group.Outdoor exercise is unlimited, as long as iniduals strictly follow social distancing rules and hygiene practices.Those who are shielding can meet outside with people from another household ndash but should not go into another personrsquos house or share food with them.Welsh Government minister for health and social services, Vaughan Gething announced the changes on Sunday, May .There are no other changes being made to the advice for those who are shielding at this stage.People who are shielding should continue to follow all the other advice previously given.They should not go shopping or attend work outside of home.They should continue to have food and medicine delivered to them.This advice comes from chief medical officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton.He said: ldquoRisk can never be completely eliminated but we advise those shielding to exercise at times that are less busy, so the risk of contact with others is reduced.ldquoWe have advised everyone in Wales to maintain social distance of two metres and keep good hygiene when meeting outdoors."For those who are shielding, strictly following these rules is vital.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am pleased that so many have been shielding so diligently ndash not only protecting themselves but also helping to protect our NHS.ldquoWe recognise how challenging these last few months, with minimal face-to-face contact with others, has been.ldquoI am incredibly proud of all those who have and continue to provide the vital support to enable people to shield.ldquoOur local authority partners, pharmacies, volunteers, and major food retailers have all pulled together to make shielding possible.The chief medical officer is continuing to develop his advice for shielding people after June .All who are shielding will receive a letter from Dr Atherton in the coming fortnight setting out the next steps. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: contact tracing system wales rolled out
story: From today, anyone who has a positive coronavirus test result will be contacted by a team of contact tracers and asked for details of everyone they have had close contact with while they have had symptoms.Close contact means anyone who has been within m of and had a face-to-face-conversation, had skin-to-skin contact with or have coughed on, or been in other forms of contact with for a minute or longer.It also means they have been within m of for more than  minutes or they have travelled in a vehicle with or sat near on public transport.All these close contacts will be followed up and will be asked to self-isolate for  days as a precaution to prevent the virus spreading further.From Monday, June  contact tracing will be supported by a new online system, which will give people the option to provide details of their close contacts electronically.Mr Gething said: ldquoTodayrsquos roll-out of the contact tracing element of our Test, Trace, Protect strategy is a signicant step forward in the gradual move out of lockdown.ldquoOver the last few months, thanks to the help of the public and the way they have followed the stay-at-home rules, we have managed to slow the spread of the virus to the point where we can today ease the regulations to enable family and friends to meet again.ldquoContact tracing is a tried and tested method of bringing outbreaks of infectious diseases under control and we hope it will do the same with coronavirus ndash but for it to be successful, we need everyonersquos help and cooperation in sharing details about their movements and contacts."We also need people to self-isolatethey may be at risk.ldquoThe scientic advice is clear ndash we need a contact tracing system in place before we begin to lt restrictions further.Health boards and local title: meet environment author stephen moss penarth bookstore online event

title: schools wales urged open august holidays
story: An announcement on the re-opening of schools is expected this week, having been closed to the vast majority of pupils since March , with local authorities being told that at least three weeks notice will be provided,But despite the scheduled summer holidays set to start in mid July, leaving only approximately three weeks of lessons at most,the National Education UnionCymru claims that plans for the six week break to be brought forward a month had been abandoned.More NewsDeaths in Vale of Glamorgan jump  per cent higher in AprilBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandMeet environment author Stephen Moss at Penarth bookstore online eventUnion secretaryDavid Evans, in a Facebook post, said that such a move would result in a -week term in the autumn with just a one-week break in the middle for the teachers, adding that thiswould mean breaking summer arrangements and resulting ldquocontractual issues, describing such plans as a ldquonon-starter.But Arfon MS Sian Gwenllian says thatbringing this yearrsquos summer holidays forward should continue to be ldquofully explored, suggesting a phased and gradual re-opening of schools in August rather than September, but onlyit was safe to do so.Plaid Cymrursquos education spokesperson claims there could beldquoeducational advantages in bringing forward the start of the autumn term.This, she added, could further pave the way for permanent changesand a re-configuring of the traditionalthree term year in a way that would be ldquoless disjointed andmore in tune with modern-day needs.ldquoThe educational advantages of bringing this yearrsquos summer holidays forward and beginning the autumn term in August should continue to be fully explored, she said.ldquoBefore the Coronavirus crisis there were on-going discussions about school term s and the need to change from three to four school terms and making the summer holidays shorter.ldquoWith need to re-visit those discussions in the wake of Coronavirus and now may be the time to consider changing school terms permanently and toreconfigurethe annual school pattern.She added that the current practice ofldquointense half terms followed by a short holiday has caused both teachers and pupils to become tired, claiming that many teacherssay that the summer term is ldquotoo long ndash especiallyfor children who are not supported with their learning at home.She concluded,ldquoAt the moment in Wales, terms are of dferent swith holidays coming irregularlyand yet research shows that continuity and progression are importantelements of learning.ldquoMany teacherssay that the summer term is too long, with the first few weeks of the autumn term being used for catch-up, especiallyfor children who are not supported with their learning at home.ldquoIn the meantime, we must crucially continue to refine remote learning. This should be central to the plans for the gradual re-opening of schools. It should also be integral to future planning too as we continue to strive to close the digital poverty ide and the attainment gap.ldquoThe focus of our education system must be on engaging with every pupil and ensuring no child is left behind.A Welsh Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe Welsh Government is working closely with unions, local authorities, scientists and education staff to decide on the next steps for education in Wales and the Minister intends to update further this week. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: check catch prepare summer september   wales schools enter next phase
story: Education minister Kirsty Williams MS says all schools will start the next phase on Monday, June , with the term extended by a week, therefore ending on Monday, July .In the next academic year, beginning in September, the intention is that the autumn half-term break will be expanded to two weeks.In each school there will be a phased approach.More storiesWelsh Government education minister Kirsty Williams sets out thinking on schools Welsh Government provides schools with new mental health supportSchools in Wales will remain closed on June , announces education minister Kirsty WilliamsYear groups will be split into cohorts with staggered starts, lessons, and breaks.This will mean, at most, a third of pupils present at any one time, though schools may need time to reach this level of operation.There will be much smaller classes, providing secure dedicated time with teachers and classmates.This time will include online and personalised classroom experience, getting children and teachers ready for a similar experience in September.Next week, the Welsh Government will publish guidance to support schools, as well as further and higher education institutions.This will include information on managing their facilities and logistical arrangements, including buildings, resources, cleaning and transport.The Government is also publishing a paper from its covid- Technical Advisory Group, representing the latest understanding of the virus with respect to children and education.Further Education colleges are ensuring that appropriate measures are being taken to re-open for face-to-face learning from Monday, June .They will prioritise those students requiring licence to practice assessments and vulnerable learners.This follows close working with government and the joint trade unions.Guidance for childcare providers will also be published in the next week, supporting them to increase the numbers of children in attendance alongside schools.Ms Williams said her announcement gave schools three and a half weeks to continue preparing for the next phase.She said: ldquoWe will use the last weeks of the summer term to make sure pupils, staff and parents are prepared ndash mentally, emotionally and practically ndash for the new normal in September.ldquo June means there will have been one full month of test, trace and protect, which will continue to expand.ldquoI can also announce that teachers will be a priority group in our new antibody-testing programme.ldquoAs we continue to keep Wales safe, this approach will be critical.ldquoThe evolving science suggests that warm weather and sunlight gives us the best opportunity to ensure more time in school.       ,params: .pushldquoWaiting until September would mean almost half a year without schooling.ldquoThat would be to the detriment to the wellbeing, learning progress and mental health of our young people.ldquoThis is and has been a worrying period for us all.ldquoI know that many will feel apprehensive.ldquoWe have not rushed this work and this decision.ldquoThe three-and-a-half-week period before the next phase also gives us time to keep watch on developments where and provides further check-points to review evidence and the roll-out of testing.ldquoThis is the best practical option that meets my five principles which underpin my decision making.ldquoI am also convinced that it is only by ing to their own school that we will see increased attendance from our more vulnerable and disadvantaged children.ldquoWorking together we will secure equity and excellence for pupils as they check in, catch up, and prepare for summer and September. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey the coronavirus pandemic in March this year.The drive thru in the Ty Verlon estate-based store is located near the roundabout which provides access to and from Wenvoe, Cardf, Dinas Powys, Sully, and Penarth.Other drive thrus to re-open include the Cardf stores at Culverhouse Cross, Excelsior Road, Cardf Bay, Longwood Drive, and Newport Road.Extensive queues formed when two drive thru reopened in Pencoed, Bridgend, on Tuesday, June .A McDonaldrsquos spokeswoman said: "This is only possible following the hard work of the teams in our  pilot restaurants."Our employees, franchisees and suppliers have worked tirelessly to implement new procedures to enable safe working so that we can now help all parts of the UK and Ireland to enjoy theof the Big Mac."With fewer employees working in our kitchens and service areas, our teams will still need your patience and support as they continue to adjust to the new ways of working."Face coverings, gloves, perspex screens and new safety and hygiene processes mean it will look dferent, it will take a little longer and as we have seen in the pilot restaurants, we expect demand will be high."Please bear with us, we will continue to put our title: shielding continue   people wales
story: Shielding continues for all generations" Shielding to continue for , people in WalesA general view of a close up of the hands of an elderly woman at home.." Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentALMOST , people will this week start receiving a letter from the chief medical Officer for Wales setting out the latest advice to protect them from coronavirus.They will be asked to continue shielding until Sunday, August , but the letter will also describe how the medical advice has changed to enable them to go outdoors to meet other people for the first time since the start of the pandemic.The shielded group are people who are classed as extremely vulnerable to developing serious illnessthey contract coronavirus because they have a specic health condition.They have been following strict shielding advice for  weeks.MORE STORIES"Check in, Catch up, Prepare for summer and September" - Wales schools to enter next phaseContact tracing system for Wales rolled-outWelsh Government lockdown message changed to Stay Local to Keep Wales SafeWalesrsquo chief medical officer, Dr Frank Atherton, said: ldquoSince the start of the pandemic, we have been focused on ensuring people who are at greatest risk are protected from coronavirus.ldquoThe spread of coronavirus is being carefully monitored ndashit gets lower, it is possible those within the shielded group will be able to do more.ldquoIf it gets higher, we may advise those people to stop going outside and to stay at home again.Earlier this week, the Welsh Government announced a change in advice for people who are shielding, based on a review of the evidence by the four UK chief medical officers.From June , everyone who is shielding are being advised they can leave their homes to meet people from another household outdoors, as long as strictly follow to social distancing rules and good hygiene measures. This includes exercising outdoors.The new August shielding date does not affect this updated advice.Dr Atherton said: ldquoWe are asking all those in the shielding group to continue to shield until August  because coronavirus has not gone away.ldquoWe want to do all we can to keep those people in this group safe and that means asking them to continue to shield.ldquoI will continue to work with my chief medical officer colleagues to review the evidence for this group and will write to them again in the summer.Everyone in the shielding group has been asked to continue to rely on their existing support networks ndash including family and friends ndashfor help with everyday tasks, such as food shopping and collecting prescription medicines.For those who do not have anyone locally, the Welsh Government has worked with local authorities and the Wales Council for Voluntary Action , major food retailers, GPs and pharmacies to ensure they can access the support they need to continue shielding.The arrangements for weekly food boxes for those people who are shielding who have no support from family or friends will continue to be in place.The Welsh Government also continues to work with supermarket retailers in Wales which offer online shopping and home delivery to make sure priority slots are available for people who are shielding.Dr Atherton added: ldquoA huge amount of work has been going on to support people who are shielding and Irsquod particularly like to thank local authorities, the WLGA, WCVA and county voluntary councils for their ongoing work and support. title: penarth church blown away response virtual sunday services
story: Members of the Tabernacle Baptist Churchhave been live streaming their brilliant virtual Sunday services via Facebook Live and Youtube, and the services have attracted hundreds of viewers, with some as far as Germany tuning in.More NewsBarry McDonalds drive thru is back in businessPupils in Wales canto school on June , Welsh Government announceBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandStarting on the second week of lockdown at the end of March, the videos have grown in popularity, and church member Jack Westmore says it is ldquosomething good to come out of a tough time.ldquoIt has been a way of bringing some familiar faces to peoplersquos homes every week, and is something for our members to look forward to, said Mr Westmore. ldquoSome are also not members and are generally interested and want to have a Sunday service.ldquoWe are very lucky that we have some brilliant musicians and tech-savvy members who have really stood up to the plate and made this lockdown bearable for so many of us.Church Elder Claire Grafton explained the impact of the virtual services, adding: ldquoWe have two elderly members who tune in, and one isnrsquot as good with the technology as the other, but one holds the screen right up to the other and they sing along. title: world environment day wales can lead charge quest truly green recovery
story: As the world marks World Environment Day , Sir David has underlined NRWrsquos commitment to supporting the Welsh Government to deliver a green recovery that prioritises sustainable economic growth and benefits the climate and our natural environment.He also outlined how Wales must lead the way on a green route out of the covid- crisis and how Walesrsquo response to the lockdown will play a critical role in determining our effectiveness - or otherwise - in responding to the climate and nature emergencies.MORE STORIESPorthkerry Park pond project improves Barry environmentCadoxton Brook flood scheme plans will go on display at Dinas Powys Community LibraryCoastal areas expected to be hit by large wavesSir David said: ldquoThe impact of covid- has brought sharply into focus the importance we place on our local environment ndash particularly when our access to it has been limited to serve a greater purpose.ldquoIt has also made the case for tackling the climate emergency starker than ever before.The pledges NRW made last year to respond to that challenge remain at the heart of everything we do.The concept of a sustainable recovery will only add momentum to our approach to tackling the climate emergency, and deeper instil the commitment needed to succeed.Looking at how a green recovery could effectively be achieved, NRW suggests that an overall package could focus on a recovery that strengthens our local economies by capitalising on the renewed sense of place and connection we now have with our communities and developing active travel measures which will help to safeguard the quality of the air we breathe.NRW also suggests developing support packages for businesses and sectors that have decarbonisation and nature-based solutions at their core and reforming and developing longer-term policy ambitions in areas such as post-Brexit agricultural and land management support, and the approach to developing a more circular economy.Sir David also reiterated the importance of approaching the green recovery as a coalition with one voice.He added: ldquoThis World Environment Day we need everyone in Wales ndash the government, the private, third and tourism sectors, environmental NGOs, the agricultural and recreational sectors and our communities across Wales - to work together to confront this global challenge head on and seize the opportunity to lead the charge for a truly green recovery. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new app crucial sorting bookings vale glamorgan recycling centre
story: First Minister Mark Drakeford announced last month that recycling centres could reopen as part of the easing of coronavirus restrictions.More than , bookings were made on the first day when they reopened in the Vale of Glamorgan ndash  bookings were made every minute.The Zipporah app called Generic, is helping people in the county to book an appointment. This is proving vital in helping recycling centres manage attendance, maintain physical distancing and reduce queuing.MORE STORIESNew app to provide specialist advice to GPs in secondsNew pound, fund to help digital firms develop technology to combat coronavirusSouth Wales freemasons donate  tablets to hospitalsResidents are also provided with clear instructions and procedures to follow before arriving and during their visit to a recycling centre.The app has also been taken up by local authorities outside Wales. Zipporah is providing it to all free of charge.Economy, Transport and North Wales Minister, Ken Skates said:ldquoThis is a fantastic example of a Welsh company taking action in a time of crisis to introduce a new product for the benefit of public services and local residents.ldquoIndications show the Generic app has already proved a success at recycling centres in the Vale of Glamorgan. This is absolutely essential in ensuring physical distancing rules are maintained and people can come and go with confidence and ease.ldquoIrsquod like to thank Zipporah and the Vale of Glamorgan Council for working collaboratively to bring a successful solution into the public domain.Zipporahrsquos technical director Scott Burton said:"Our appointment solution has already been incredibly effective especially in facilitating the organised re-opening of recycling centres ndash not only in Wales but also across England and Scotland.ldquoAs well as keeping recycling centres running smoothly, Zipporah technology has been crucial in allowing social distancing to be maintained ndash upholding the safety of both the public and staff alike.ldquoWersquore delighted with how successful the system has been in benefiting those using during this challenging period.Deputy Minister for Housing and Local Government, Hannah Blythyn said:ldquoWe have had to adapt our ways of working, since the coronavirus outbreak and it is fantastic to see local authorities and businesses coming together and using innovative technology to ensure key public services are maintained.ldquoEnsuring the safety of staff and the public at recycling centres is vital.The Generic app has not only helped to achieve this but has allowed recycling centres to run smoothly while adopting social distancing. I hope wersquoll see more of this collaborative working in the future as we respond to the pandemic.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Peter King said: ldquoWersquore delighted with how smoothly our household waste recycling centres have been able to reopen after a period of closure.ldquoAs anticipated demand for these facilities was extremely high, but thanks to proper planning and the hard work of council staff many potential problems relating to queuing and waiting times have been avoided.ldquoThe implementation of a booking system was crucial to the reopening operation and wersquod like to thank Zipporah for their support.ldquoTheyrsquove provided us with reliable and robust software that has stood up well to signicant pressure.Vale resident, Stuart Evans said: ldquoAfter a couple of months of having a full garden of shelving units, carpet, underlay, I was so grateful to be able to get to the recycling centre in Barry.ldquoTime slots worked perfectly and it felt so lsquonormalrsquo.ldquoStaff were very organised and helpful. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: wales make face masks compulsory public transport
story: Mark Drakeford said Englands decision to bring in a requirement for coverings had raised issues for people commuting between the two countries.It came as Public Health Wales said a further four people had died after testing positive for coronavirus, taking the total number of deaths to ,, while the number of positive cases grew by  to ,.More NewsLuxury car manufacturer Aston Martin to axe  jobsMans efforts toWorld War One Penarth soldiers plaque found in New ZealandPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideOn Friday, Mr Drakeford was questioned about his governments position on non-medical coverings after a trade union representing doctors in Wales said bringing in rules would help control the spread of Covid- and save lives.Mr Drakeford told the Governments daily press briefing in Cardf: "The context for face coverings has changed because of an announcement made yesterday in England about mandatory use of face masks on public transport."That will not come in until June , and that gives us a short number of days in order to consider the position here in Wales recognising that changed context."Mr Drakeford said a "definitive statement" on the issue would be made in the first part of next week, and that detailed questions about Englands new rules would be explored with ministers and officials in Westminster.But he said the UK Government had not discussed or given advanced notice of the decision with Wales, and questioned whether England was concerned with "making the headline, and then worrying about the detail afterwards"."I wish that wed had a chance to explore this with the UK Government before they made the announcements," he said."That would have allowed us to have some answers to the questions that I raised today before the event rather than after the event."But while on the bulk of issues we continue to be able to have discussion and co-operation in advance of decision making, in a small number of cases we hear about it only after the decision has been made."He added: "Were going to have to use the time we now have to find out from them the extent to which they have got answers to these questions in advance of making the decision, or whether its a matter of making the headline, and then worrying about the detail afterwards."Mr Drakeford said the advice from the chief medical officer for Wales remained that wearing face masks gave people "some marginal extra protection" but was not sufficient to make it mandatory."The chief medical officer has expressed his anxieties that people might do more risky things because they think a face mask offers them protection, which it doesnt," Mr Drakeford said."But context changes because in England it is mandatory to use face masks while on public transport."Trains and roads between north and south Wales weave in and out of the border all the time and in a sheer practical sense, we have to think through whether having separate regimes is a possibility when you can leave on a train that starts in Wales, goes into England, comes back into Wales, goes back into England, comes back into Wales."Earlier on Friday the British Medical AssociationWales called on the Welsh Government to change its stance on non-medical face coverings, and ensure a supply are available to the public.The trade unions council chair for Wales, Dr David Bailey, said: "BMA Cymru Wales advocates the wearing of face coverings by the public in areas where they cannot socially distance."There still remains a considerable risk of infection, and emerging evidence has shown thatmouths and noses are covered when people are in areas where they cannot socially distance, it may help in controlling the spread of infection of Covid- and therefore save lives."BMA Cymru Wales is calling on the Welsh Government to change their position immediately, to lessen the risk of the public spreading the virus."Wales main train operator, Transport for Wales, said it would "work collaboratively" with partners to ensure passengers were kept safe travelling across borders.A spokesman said: "The cross-border nature of our network means that we will continue to work collaboratively with industry partners to ensure customers understand how they can travel safely as they travel between Wales and England."The safety of our colleagues and customers is our top priority and wed like to reinforce the message to stay local and only use public transportthe journey is essential and theres no other travel alternative." article_url   content_id   site_id title: south wales detectorists discover treasure nine occasions
story: The British Museum said it was pleasing to see local museums across the country acquiring these "important archaeological objects", but urged treasure hunters to follow the laws surrounding metal detecting.More NewsNew app crucial in sorting bookings at Vale of Glamorgan recycling centreLuxury car manufacturer Aston Martin to axe  jobsPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideIn , there were nine treasure finds reported to Central South Wales Coroners Court, which is responsible for holding treasure inquests.It means a total of  discoveries in the last three years in the area.Across England and Wales, , finds were reported last year ndash  per cent more than the year before.Lincolnshire was the best area for treasure, with  finds last year alone. In contrast, no treasure whatsoever was found in  areas.The Treasure Act, introduced in , defines treasure as discoveries older than  years.These include coins, prehistoric metallic objects and artefacts that are at least  per cent precious metal such as gold or silver.All potential treasure finds are processed by the British Museum, whose experts advise coroners on whether the find fits the definition of treasure.If a coroner rules that it is treasure, both local and national museums are given the chance to acquire the pieces, and the finder will be paid a sum depending on the treasures value.Butthe find is determined not to be treasure, or no museums want it, then it is ed to the treasure hunter.A Ministry of Justice report on last years treasure finds said the number of discoveries has been steadily increasing since the Treasure Act commenced ndash rising from just  finds in .There were  inquests concluded last year, with more than  per cent ing a verdict of treasure.Ian Richardson, treasure registrar at the British Museum, said: "The purpose of the Treasure Act is to enable important archaeological objects to be acquired by museums, for the benefit of all."It is pleasing to see local museums interested in acquiring a number of these findsthey are declared Treasure."Anyone fortunate enough to discover something they think is treasure must report their finding to the coroner within two weeks, so the court can hold an inquest to decide who should get the to keep it.Failure to do so can result in an unlimited fine or up to three months in prison.With metal detecting being permitted again as lockdown lts, Mr Richardson urged people to continue to follow the Code of Practice for Responsible Metal Detecting and report their discoveries, including Treasure. title: bp slash   jobs due coronavirus
story: The company said the move will ldquosignicantly impact senior levels of management in the business, with its top leadership roles to be cut by a third.It said the majority of the redundancies will be made by the end of this year, after the business took a major hit from the coronavirus pandemic.BP said the cuts are part of plans for the business to cut its operating costs by . billion dollarsfor new financial year, although the cuts ldquowill likely have to go even further.In an email to staff, BP chief executive Bernard Looney said: ldquoWe will now begin a process that will see close to , people leaving BP ndash most by the end of this year.ldquoThe majority of people affected will be in office-based jobs.ldquoWe are protecting the frontline of the company and, as always, prioritising safe and reliable operations.The company employs , people across the globe, meaning the cuts will slash the size of its workforce by %.Group leaders and senior level leaders, who will be worst hit by the cuts, will also not be given any pay rises until March  at the earliest, while BP will not pay any cash bonus this year.The news comes less than two months after BP increased the idend that it pays to shareholders, despite a major hit from the pandemic.It will likely raise eyebrows within the business as staff eye BPrsquos long-term rival Shell, which decided to slash its idend by two thirds ndash the first time the shareholder payout was lowered since the Second World War.Mr Looney said that the pandemic and a recent drop in the price of oil meant BP has to slash spending.ldquoThe oil price has plunged well below the level we need to turn a profit. We are spending much, much more than we make ndash I am talking millions of dollars, every day. And as a result, our net debt rose by six billion US dollarsin the first quarter, he said.Mr Looney has set out to considerably transform the oil giant after stepping up to the top job in February.As he replaced American Bob Dudley, Mr Looney promised that BP would be an emissions-neutral company by the middle of the century.However, his commitment to the challenge of global warming has been questioned by campaign groups.So far the ambition has merely been expressed as a vague goal, with few specics.Mr Looney has promised to lay out a more thorough road map in September." GardensNewsPoliticsCouncil investigating possibility of holding virtual eventsArmagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough council will investigate the possibility of holding some of its events virtually.By The NewsroomThursday, th May , : pm""The proposal to look at the feasibility of hosting certain events remotely was raised at Tuesday evening’s virtual meeting as members discussed a report recommending all Council led events are cancelled until the end of August.Council’s Head of Tourism, Artsand Culture, Brian Johnston, advised members there will be a further report in June that will give consideration to events held until the end of December .The report, circulated to members before the meeting, states that at present, events involving gatherings of people are not permitted and it is anticipated that when they are, other controls such as social distancing will be required.Some of the events recommended for cancellation include Buskfest in Banbridge Town Centre on June , Armed Forces Day in Banbridge Town Centre and Rugby Club on June  and the Seven Hills Blues Festival in Armagh which runs from August -.Other events for later in the year, including the Georgian Festival in Armagh and Halloween events across the borough and Christmas and twilight markets are all marked for further consideration.When asked by Banbridge Sinn Fein councillor, Kevin Savage why an estimate of council savings was not includedin the report Mr Johnston said Council would have spent £, on the events it now proposes to cancel.However, he did advise that not all of that will be saved by Council as some contractual obligations will need to be met.SDLP group leader, Councillor Thomas O’Hanlon raisedthe possibility of holding some of these events virtually.“We are encouraging businesses to do things online,” said the Armagh representative.“If we could look at some of these events happening between now and Christmas and seethere is an opportunity to do similar with them, could we have that explored and brought back in due course ”Lurgan councillor Liam Mackle said: “I would be very happy with some virtual events taking place in the months ahead.”The Sinn Fein representative then proposed that Council officers explore this idea and report back in due course with the proposal seconded by Councillor O’Hanlon.A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading title: mcdonald s in omagh to re open today
story: TodayOmagh McDonald’s will reopen for Drive Thru with new measures in place to help keep employees and customers safe. This follows a successful pilot in May.A spokesperson said: With restaurant teams adjusting to new procedures to enable safe working and social distancing, things may take a little longer – and high demand is anticipated. McDonald’s and its franchisees are working closely with local authorities and the police, and may determine that it is necessary to close Drive Thru lanesqueues cause disruption at busier sites or put employees or customers at risk.To help create a safe experience for everyone, McDonald’s has introduced a number of changes to their restaurants, including:* Social distancing has been introduced in the kitchens and service areas to help create a safe working environment for restaurant teams.* Perspex screens at Drive Thru windows and employees wearing protective equipment, as well as Perspex screens and floor markings in specic areas in the restaurant and kitchen.* All McDonald’s employees will be asked to confirm they are fit and able to work and contactless thermometers will be used to take employee temperatures on arrival at work for every sht.*Ensuring our delivery procedures with couriers are contactless for both our people and our customers*Restaurants willwith smaller teams, offering a limited menu* and operating reduced hours.* Encouraging capped spend for Drive Thru and McDelivery at pound per order, and customers are encouraged to pay by contactless payment methods* For those visiting Drive Thrus, customers can browse the menu, order and pay ahead using the My McDonald’s AppAs employees and the business adapt to a new way of working, McDonald’s would like to thank customers for their continued support and patience.Between  and  June  restaurants will be open in Northern Ireland, either for Drive Thru or McDelivery.
